summary: How does the aurean believe actually work? Is it full on reverence and worship of the legendary pokémon involved? or is it more...
question: How does the aurean believe actually work? Is it full on reverence and worship of the legendary pokémon involved? or is it more of an appeasement of the legendaries? The sootopolitans are only required to guard various locations throughout hoenn(as well as a few outside of hoenn), mostly to prevent another battle between Groudon and Kyogre. Beyond that only the elder, the guardian, and the shaman have duties outside of that.
answer:
It’s not appeasement, but it’s also not reverence. It’s more… respect. Xerneas gives life and Yveltal takes it, but neither is good nor evil– they’re just balanced, and we acknowledge that. We don’t live in fear of them, but we do respect them. 

Many of our holidays are of the “someone tried to wipe us out and we survived” variety, but several are based around the Legendaries. We celebrate the new year, the day when the world was born, near the beginning of fall (the exact date varies because it’s based on a different calendar), and ten days later we observe the Day of Atonement, when we apologize for our wrongs in the previous year. On the Day of Atonement, Xerneas and Yveltal come before us (metaphorically) and ask us to choose between life and death; through apologizing to those we hurt in the previous year, we choose life.

Of course, there’s the weekly rest day, when we’re not supposed to do any work in memory of how, on the seventh day of the world’s existence, Xerneas and Yveltal rested. I don’t always keep this one, but it’s nice to observe once in a while.

Today, the Legendaries are rarely seen, but the stories are full of people who argued with them and succeeded. There’s the one where Yveltal was going to destroy a city because the people were terrible; one of the Aurean people’s ancestors asked Yveltal to reconsider destruction if it could find 50 good people in the city, then 40, and argued it down to 10 good people. And there’s the time when there was no rain, so a man drew a circle on the ground and yelled at Xerneas that he would not leave unless it sent rain to bring the plants back to life; when Xerneas sent a little bit of rain, he kept yelling until Xerneas sent a storm. So the relationship is respectful, but not reverent.

It’s not appeasement, but it’s also not reverence. It’s more… respect. Xerneas gives life and Yveltal takes it, but neither is good nor evil– they’re just balanced, and we acknowledge that. We don’t live in fear of them, but we do respect them. 

Many of our holidays are of the “someone tried to wipe us out and we survived” variety, but several are based around the Legendaries. On the Day of Atonement, Xerneas and Yveltal come before us (metaphorically) and ask us to choose between life and death; through apologizing to those we hurt in the previous year, we choose life.

Of course, there’s the weekly rest day, when we’re not supposed to do any work in memory of how, on the seventh day of the world’s existence, Xerneas and Yveltal rested. I don’t always keep this one, but it’s nice to observe once in a while.

So the relationship is respectful, but not reverent.

It’s not appeasement, but it’s also not reverence. It’s more… respect. Xerneas gives life and Yveltal takes it, but neither is good nor evil– they’re just balanced, and we acknowledge that. We don’t live in fear of them, but we do respect them.

On the Day of Atonement, Xerneas and Yveltal come before us (metaphorically) and ask us to choose between life and death; through apologizing to those we hurt in the previous year, we choose life.

Of course, there’s the weekly rest day, when we’re not supposed to do any work in memory of how, on the seventh day of the world’s existence, Xerneas and Yveltal rested. I don’t always keep this one, but it’s nice to observe once in a while.

So the relationship is respectful, but not reverent.
trail.content:
It’s not appeasement, but it’s also not reverence. It’s more… respect. Xerneas gives life and Yveltal takes it, but neither is good nor evil– they’re just balanced, and we acknowledge that. We don’t live in fear of them, but we do respect them.

We celebrate the new year, the day when the world was born, near the beginning of fall (the exact date varies because it’s based on a different calendar), and ten days later we observe the Day of Atonement, when we apologize for our wrongs in the previous year. On the Day of Atonement, Xerneas and Yveltal come before us (metaphorically) and ask us to choose between life and death; through apologizing to those we hurt in the previous year, we choose life.

Of course, there’s the weekly rest day, when we’re not supposed to do any work in memory of how, on the seventh day of the world’s existence, Xerneas and Yveltal rested. I don’t always keep this one, but it’s nice to observe once in a while.

There’s the one where Yveltal was going to destroy a city because the people were terrible; one of the Aurean people’s ancestors asked Yveltal to reconsider destruction if it could find 50 good people in the city, then 40, and argued it down to 10 good people. And there’s the time when there was no rain, so a man drew a circle on the ground and yelled at Xerneas that he would not leave unless it sent rain to bring the plants back to life; when Xerneas sent a little bit of rain, he kept yelling until Xerneas sent a storm. So the relationship is respectful, but not reverent.

blog.name: inikavulpixelreviews
blog.title: Let's Talk About Pokemon!
blog.description:
Reviewing my personal opinion on every single Pokemon! Yes, all 809 of them!
(Mostly) Daily Uploads, 3 PM EST.

summary: Let’s Talk About Pokemon - Pancham and Pangoro
title: Let’s Talk About Pokemon - Pancham and Pangoro
body:
674: Pancham

Oh, another bear Pokemon, huh? Of course, a panda Pokemon would have to be a big, fat, cute, and uselessly lazy stereotype of a panda right? Well, as you can tell, Pancham’s nowhere close to that. This scrappy little kid is nothing short of a trouble-maker with an attitude. But for now, is just a Fighting type. What a fun direction to take a panda! It’s got a fun personality with a little bully sort of look. A bit like that anime cool-dude stereotype where they have something like a twig in their mouth, huh?

Personal Score: 7/10

And then…

675: Pangoro

Pangoro, a friggin panda Pokemon, turns into a big delinquent bear with a stick in its mouth and a full-on trench coat. Which is funny on its own how a panda Pokemon would turn out so mean. But it turns out this Pokemon only evolves when you have another Dark Type in the party; making Pangoro a Pokemon that learned from a bad influence that is what is basically the Asshole Type. It itself becoming Dark/Fighting. And that’s just hilarious, not to mention a cool way to get this line’s personality across through a game mechanic.

Personal Score: 7/10

Ya finally did it Gamefreak, ya got me to like one of these dang bears.

Overall:

Gen 6 has been a little bit of a mixed bag so far, huh? Well, tomorrow is when things get nuts.

[Archive]

blog.name: weirdandwackypokefusions
blog.title: Well that's strange!
blog.description:
Welcome!  I create, using the all-mighty classic Microsoft XP Paint, my own pokemon fusions. All the sprites come from pokestadium and usually people on deviantart/ the xy/sun&moon sprite project. I don't own any of the sprite used, I just fuse them! 
REQUESTS ARE OPEN! Ask Box: 3/15.
PLEASE FEEL FREE TO DRAW MY FUSIONS!!  I absolutely love it when people draw them! There's no need to ask either! Just make sure you tag me so them I can see it!
I hope you enjoy my fusions!

summary:
Snody Corn Snorunt and Candy Corn fusion Nutritional Information: Sugar Type Ability: Sugar Head - 

Protects the Pokefood from...
caption:
Snody Corn

Snorunt and Candy Corn fusion

Nutritional Information:

Sugar Type

Ability: Sugar Head -  Protects the Pokefood from recoil damage

Signature Move - Sweet Defence - Snody Corn calls other Snody Corns to help it attack the opponent. 20 Power, 95 Accuracy. Multi hit move. 2-5 hits. Sugar Type.

The Sugar Shell Pokemon

Snody Corn live in groups of 5 and hunt for sweets and candy from unsuspecting children.  If a Snody Corn is about to be eaten, it will call some allies to attack the person or creature who is about to eat it. 

Day two of the Halloween event and we have a Snorunt and Candy Corn fusion suggested by @dungeonraided. It was quite fun to match the colours on this one.
